RMPDescription: Valero Refining Update  - Alky Unit Removed

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
VALERO REFINING -TEXAS, L.P.
Bill Greehey Refineries - East Plant

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES


At Valero Refining Company - Texas L.P. (Bill Greehey Refineries - East Plant, Corpus Christi, TX), we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner. We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:


- A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation,

- A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases,

- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs,

- A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule,

- An overview of our emergency response program,

- An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, or the environment,

- The certifications that EPA's rule requires us to provide,

- The detailed information (data elements) about our risk management program.



2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Bill Greehey Refineries - East Plant is one of the earliest refineries built in the Corpus Christi area. Dating back to 1942, the refinery was originally built as a defense plant for World War II. In 2001, Valero acquired the East Plant facility from El Paso Energy, adding 95,000 BPD capacity. The East Plant is located less than a mile from Valero's West Plant. The East Plant facility is capable of processing heavy, high-sulfur crude oil into light p

roducts, including conventional gasoline, diesel, jet fuel, petrochemicals, propane, butane, and light naphthas. In addition, the refinery produces multiple grades of asphalt and petroleum coke.

Clean fuels produced at Bill Greehey Refineries are marketed in the Northeastern United States, and Texas in areas where the Environmental Protection Agency has mandated their use.  Ultra low-sulfur diesel fuel and some petrochemical feedstocks are also produced.  The regulated substances are contained within the tank farm and process units. Some process units may contain regulated substances, but are either in mixtures that do not meet the EPA definition of a flammable mixture, or are below the RMP threshold quantities.

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us to effectively manage the hazards that may be posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these substances EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release.



3 KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS


The RMP rule requires that we conduct studies to identify worst-case scenario(s) for each RMP-regulated process at our facility. A summary of those applicable worst-case and alternate release scenarios including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario is provided in the appropriate section of this Risk Management Plan. 


We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.



4 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS


We maintain a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and to ensure safe operations. The accident prevention programs in place include:


OSHA PSM elements, including

:

- employee participation programs, 

- process safety information, 

- process hazard analyses, 

- operating procedures and training, 

- mechanical integrity programs with training, 

- contractor programs, 

- incident investigation programs, 

- management of change, 

- pre-startup safety reviews, 

- compliance audits, and 

- hot work and safe work programs. 



Additionally, Valero Bill Greehey Refineries - East Plant has implemented various safety programs addressing:

- safe personnel protective clothing and equipment,

- hearing protection,

- safe entry and exit controls, impact protection and secondary containment controls,

- controls on locating temporary buildings, and 

- a detailed analysis and adherence to generally accepted industry codes and standards.



Valero Bill Greehey Refineries - East Plant has made every effort to assure compliance with OSHA PSM. Program improvements have been implemented following PSM audits with the latest occurring in 2015. Accordingly, the dates provided in Section 7, Prevention Program Level 3, represent the latest updates to the program elements.


As part of our prevention program, we have implemented many chemical-specific prevention steps. For flammables, we have adopted several API, NFPA, insurance company, ASME, ANSI, and other codes and standards. Additional prevention activities continue to be identified and implemented as a result of our on-going process hazard analyses.


The individual elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases. Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.


Valero Bill Greehey Refineries - East Plant is also an OSHA VPP STAR site, and was re-approved in 2017.



5 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HIS

TORY


We keep records for all significant chemical releases that occur at our refinery. The Valero Bill Greehey Refineries - East Plant has an excellent history of accident prevention. We investigate incidents very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring. Over the last five years there have been no releases of regulated substances at the East Plant.  


6 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM


We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with Corpus Christi and Nueces County Emergency Response Agencies (fire department, police department, Refinery Terminal Fire Company, and Local Emergency Planning Committee).

The facility Emergency Response Team operates under the Incident Command System, with the Incident Commander operating from designated Emergency Command Centers.  

Valero Bill Greehey Refineries also maintain an onsite fully trained emergency response team called VALSTAR.



7 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY


We are continuously investigating and reviewing technology and / or applications that could possibly enhance our safety efforts. We are constantly reviewing and revising existing procedures, developing new procedures, and researching methods to increase employee awareness. We are continuously using learnings from incident investigations to improve our processes.
